Program_Description_R3: Students study architecture from the time period 1800-1900. Students will also spend time in each lesson drawing in their journals. The study of architecture helps students visualize what life was like for people in the past and how they went about their daily lives. Architecture also helps students have a greater appreciation for what makes homes and buildings structurally sound and aesthetically pleasing.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Could be modified easily for students in Grades 5-6 if combining students.
Subject: Architecture

Program_Description_R3: Students study famous buildings from 1800-1900 and 100 BC-350 AD.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Suitable for Grade 8 students with minimal adjustment if combining.
Subject: Architecture

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: Students learn â€œto see correctly, to set down truthfully and freely the facts seen, and to store the mind with definite mental images for future referenceâ€ (Glass 13). Draw using large arm movements- differentiating between writing and drawing skills. Be introduced to silhouettes and observational drawing. Begin understanding the medium of soft pastels. Foundational concepts in painting such as proper brush etiquette, drawing with a brush through simple brush forms, and controlling watercolor. Students will also learn basic color theory such as color mixing. Skills covered are foundational to all preceding visual art skills.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: If students are in Grade 5 and below and have not had formal art lessons, they should begin with Level 1. However, those with prior art knowledge can take the Level 1-3 fast-track lessons and then continue with Level 4.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.002*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 1|002.001.001*Brushwork: Elementary Brush-Forms->Art: Level 1

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: New concepts covered are understanding design elements, the principle of proportion, and drawing cylindrical objects. Continue to use and understand the medium of soft pastels. Deeper study of color theory includes contrast, complementary colors, mixing colors, and changing values. Continue to build on understanding and manipulating watercolor. Build confidence and understanding in observation and communication that will translate across the curriculum.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
If students are in grade 5 and below and have not had formal art lessons, they should begin with Level 1. However, those with prior art knowledge can take the Level 1-3 fast-track lessons and then continue with Level 4. See course descriptions for specific content covered at each level.

Prerequisite: Level 1 or appropriate skill proficiency.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 002.001.001*Brushwork: Elementary Brush-Forms->Art: Level 2|003.001.002*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 2

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: Students continue to strengthen their brush forms and apply those forms to different plant and animal images, moving from copying the book to using the mind's eye and trained hand to create their pieces of art. Students continue to strengthen their color theory through value scales and monochromatic painting with watercolors, acrylic paint, and pastels. In drawing, students study the design principle of proportion and begin learning perspective through the study of ellipses with many opportunities to apply this understanding through drawing and other projects.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
If students are in grade 5 and below and have not had formal art lessons, they should begin with Level 1. However, those with prior art knowledge can take the Level 1-3 fast-track lessons and then continue with Level 4.

Prerequisite: Level 2 or appropriate skill proficiency.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*Brushwork: Elementary Brush-Forms->Art: Level 3|003.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 3

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: New skills are introduced are simple perspective, landscape drawing, light source, shadows, tonal variations, and using a drawing board. Charcoal is introduced as a new medium. Mathematical drawing is explored through tessellations. More complex color theory with tertiary and complementary colors, an expanded color wheel, mixing browns, and value change in color. New watercolor skills: wash, graduated wash, and lifting. Continue strengthening skills with soft pastels. Brush drawing assignments span the year as opposed to one term.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
If students are in grade 5 and below and have not had formal art lessons, they should begin with Level 1. However, those with prior art knowledge can take the Level 1-3 fast-track lessons and then continue with Level 4.

Prerequisite: Level 3 or appropriate skill proficiency.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 4|002.001.000*Brush Drawing as Applied to Natural Forms and Common Objects->Art: Level 4

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: Learn design elements; shape, line, form, etc., using an eraser as a drawing tool, and geometrical object drawing through drawing landscapes and still lifes. Begin learning to draw the human figure in action as well as facial proportions, and drawing the human bust. Continue with color theory; learn how adding neutral brings down the intensity of a color and create multiple shades of a color. Apply color theory through projects. Strengthen brush drawing and watercolor skills through projects. New watercolor technique of layering.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
If students are in grade 5 and below and have not had formal art lessons, they should begin with Level 1. However, those with prior art knowledge can take the Level 1-3 fast-track lessons and then continue with Level 4. 

Prerequisite: Level 4 or appropriate skill proficiency.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 002.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 5|003.001.000*Brush Drawing as Applied to Natural Forms and Common Objects->Art: Level 5

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: Practice applying drawing skills with the brush and watercolor techniques. Practice underpainting. Grow in watercolor abilities by continued practice. Draw spheres, study body proportions, foreshortening, curvature, overlapping, texture drawing, and highlighting. Color theory: notan, contrast, monochrome, color studies, and circular value scales.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
If students are in grade 6-8, they should begin with the fast-track lessons and then move on to Level 4. 

Prerequisite: Level 5 or appropriate skill proficiency.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*Brush Drawing as Applied to Natural Forms and Common Objects->Art: Level 6|001.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 6

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: Learn a new color wheel by introducing new primary colors, mixing new browns, as well as understanding and applying color intensity and color tone. Continue mastering watercolor skills through brush drawing projects as well as learning the salt technique. Focus on composition and applying texture and tonal value to still life drawing using specific light sources. Revisit all of the basics with the new medium of graphite.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
If students are in grade 6 or above, they should begin with the fast-track lessons and then move on to Level 4. 

Prerequisite: Level 6 or appropriate skill proficiency.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 002.001.000*Brush Drawing as Applied to Natural Forms and Common Objects->Art: Level 7|002.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 7

Program_Description_R3: Skills Focus: Continue in the new expanded color wheel, as well as learn about contrasting colors, color charting, split complements, and analogous colors. Learn and apply new ways to create texture and value through hatching and stippling. Understand pointillism. Continue working on portraiture. Understand how to paint light in watercolor and continue to strengthen watercolor skills.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
If students are in grade 6 or above, they should begin with the fast-track lessons and then move on to Level 4. 

Prerequisite: Level 7 or appropriate skill proficiency.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 000.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Level 8

Program_Description_R3: An accelerated course through art concepts covered in Art Levels 1-3.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: If students are in grade 6 or above or have prior experience with art, they should begin with the fast-track lessons and then move on to Level 4 Art.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 002.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: Fast Track|003.001.000*Brushwork: Elementary Brush-Forms->Art: Fast Track

Program_Description_R3: This High School Fast Track for Art Lessons is designed for students with minimal background in Art and/or just beginning Alveary during the high school years. Students will complete all previous eight levels of art lessons in a fast-paced sequence. Students will need a variety of art materials on hand to successfully complete this course.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Students can slow down the pace of lessons to their own pace and spread the course over multiple years if desired. Because of this flexibility, younger students interested in art could also choose to take this course instead of the Fast Track for lower grades.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*Drawing, Design, and Craft-Work->Art: High School Fast Track|002.001.000*Color: A Course in Mastering the Art of Mixing Colors->Art: High School Fast Track|003.001.000*Brush Drawing as Applied to Natural Forms and Common Objects->Art: High School Fast Track

Program_Description_R3: Students study art from 1800-1900. The lesson plans include discussion prompts that tie the artwork to what is being learned in Art Instruction, and other books and resources help students further their relationship with the art studied and consider how art intersects with the large questions of life.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: There is one set of lesson plans for students in all grades, which makes this an ideal course to study in a multi-age setting. All lessons begin the same, but extensions increase the length and sophistication of the content.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 001.003.000*Our Work: Grades 1-2->Picture Study|001.003.000*Our Work: Grade 3->Picture Study|001.003.000*Our Work: Grades 4-6->Picture Study|001.003.000*Our Work: Grades 7-8->Picture Study|001.003.000*Our Work: Grades 9-12->Picture Study|001.003.000*Art Print Set->Picture Study

Program_Description_R3: This is a High School elective course. Students study Art History through hands-on projects. Each term will focus on a different breadth of history and the art that was important to that time, bringing together and putting in chronological order many of the art pieces we have studied during Picture Study. Each term, students will be assigned four to six projects based on the history they are surveying. The projects will range from sculpture to fresco to abstract painting. Students will need a variety of art materials on hand to successfully complete this course.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Suitable for interested 8th graders, though concepts are better understood with greater age development. No prior Art Instruction or Picture Study experience is required to complete this course.
Subject: Art
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*The Arts: A Visual Encyclopedia->Art History|001.001.000*Children's Book of Art->Art History

Program_Description_R3: Discover the earthâ€™s continents, the changing seasons, latitude and longitude, map-making, and topographical features. Use a globe, wall maps, and models to explore the concept of place by taking an in-depth look at â€œhomeâ€ in North America. Students make models and maps of places that are important to them such as their room, home, and yard.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: All students in Grade 1 should take this course. Students in Grades 2-3 who have never studied geography may also benefit, though they could likely work at a faster pace.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*Elementary Geography->Geography: Grade 1|001.001.000*Me on the Map->Geography: Grade 1|001.001.000*What Makes Day and Night->Geography: Grade 1|001.002.000*United States Atlas 7th Ed.->Geography: Grade 1|002.001.000*The Reasons for Seasons->Geography: Grade 1|003.001.000*Down Comes the Rain->Geography: Grade 1

Program_Description_R3: Join the Page family as they travel from California to Washington, D.C. While this story is set in the U.S.A., the point of the book is really to explore basic geography concepts such as landforms, water bodies, maps, and regions, so it is suitable for students from any nation. Students use the globe, atlases, and models. Students also make models and draw maps of places important to them such as their neighborhood.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: This course progresses chronologically over two years. Students who did not take Geography Foundations may wish to incorporate those lessons into the afternoons. This course is intended as a precursor to Grade 3; however, the levels may be reversed in order to combine students.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*50 Adventures in the 50 States->Geography: Grade 2 (U.S.)|001.001.000*Cross Country: Geography for Children->Geography: Grade 2 (U.S.)|001.001.000*Making Your Own Maps->Geography: Grade 2 (U.S.)|001.001.000*Redwoods->Geography: Grade 2 (U.S.)|001.002.000*United States Atlas 7th Ed.->Geography: Grade 2 (U.S.)|003.002.000*Student World Atlas 6th Ed.->Geography: Grade 2 (U.S.)

Program_Description_R3: Explore each region of Canada, its geological features, cultural geography, symbols, and varied ecosystems. Along the way, students practice their mapping skills by making models and drawing places local to them, such as their neighborhood.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Students who did not take Geography Foundations may wish to incorporate those lessons into the afternoons.
Subject: Geography

Program_Description_R3: Join the Page family as they travel from California to Washington, D.C. While this story is set in the U.S.A., the point of the book is really to explore basic geography concepts such as landforms, water bodies, maps, and regions, so it is suitable for students from any nation. Students use the globe, atlases, and models. Students also make models and draw maps of places important to them such as their neighborhood.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: This course progresses chronologically over two years. Students who did not take Geography Foundations may wish to incorporate those lessons into the afternoons. This course is intended to follow Grade 2; however, the levels may be reversed in order to combine students.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*50 Adventures in the 50 States->Geography: Grade 3 (U.S.)|001.001.000*Cross Country: Geography for Children->Geography: Grade 3 (U.S.)|001.002.000*United States Atlas 7th Ed.->Geography: Grade 3 (U.S.)|001.002.000*Student World Atlas 6th Ed.->Geography: Grade 3 (U.S.)|002.001.000*Grandma Gatewood Hikes the Appalachian Trail->Geography: Grade 3 (U.S.)

Program_Description_R3: Explore each region of Canada, its geological features, cultural geography, symbols, and varied ecosystems. Along the way, students practice their mapping skills by making models and drawing places local to them, such as their neighborhood.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Students who did not take Geography Foundations may wish to incorporate those lessons into the afternoons.
Subject: Geography

Program_Description_R3: Travel along rivers, across continents, and along trade routes significant during this year's time period (1800-1900). Explore the physical and human geography (including economy and culture) of each region through reading, map work, and models. Students will also engage in map activities that focus on their local region.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: This course is the same for 4th-6th graders. Lesson plans may include more advanced map skills for older students.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.002.000*Student World Atlas 6th Ed.->Geography: Grades 4-6|001.003.000*David Livingstone: African Explorer->Geography: Grades 4-6|001.003.000*Africa Is Not a Country->Geography: Grades 4-6

Program_Description_R3: Students read about the story of cartography from ancient Mesopotamia up through the discovery of Antarctica in the late 1800s and draw maps along the way. The course finishes with a term of historical geography where students follow the steps of travelers from the 19th century.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: The first two terms are the same every year and shared between both US and Canadian courses. Term 3 changes for each historical time period.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.002.000*Student World Atlas 6th Ed.->Geography: Grade 7 (U.S.)|001.002.000*United States Atlas 7th Ed.->Geography: Grade 7 (U.S.)|001.002.000*Mapping the World with Art->Geography: Grade 7 (U.S.)|003.003.000*This Strange Wilderness: The Life and Art of John James Audubon->Geography: Grade 7 (U.S.)

Program_Description_R3: Students read about the story of cartography from ancient Mesopotamia up through the discovery of Antarctica in the late 1800s and draw maps along the way. The course finishes with a term of historical geography where students follow the steps of Canadian explorers from the 19th century and learn about Canadian provinces through map work.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: The first two terms are the same every year and shared between both US and Canadian courses. Term 3 brings in resources from the historical time period and is specific to Canadian students.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.002.000*Mapping the World with Art->Geography: Grade 7 (Canada)|003.002.000*Canadian Student Atlas->Geography: Grade 7 (Canada)

Program_Description_R3: Students focus on world and US geography using maps, illustrations, and historical narratives about travelers during the 19th century.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: This course is different for each of the historical time periods, but always retains a topical focus on US geography.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.002.000*Our States Have Crazy Shapes->Geography: Grade 8 (U.S.)|001.002.000*United States Atlas 7th Ed.->Geography: Grade 8 (U.S.)|001.002.000*Student World Atlas 6th Ed.->Geography: Grade 8 (U.S.)|003.003.000*This Strange Wilderness: The Life and Art of John James Audubon->Geography: Grade 8 (U.S.)

Program_Description_R3: Students study various natural features of Canada's provinces and territories and create a detailed, illustrated map over the course of the year. They also read a travelogue from the year's historical period.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: The Canadian mapping exercises are the same each year, but the reading component changes for each of the historical time periods.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.002.000*Canadian Student Atlas->Geography: Grade 8 (Canada)

Program_Description_R3: Students learn current and historical aspects of regional and world geography with map work.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Also suitable for students in Grades 10-12.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*Prisoners of Geography: Ten Maps That Explain Everything About the World->Geography: Grade 9|001.003.000*Five Months on the Missouri River: Paddling a Dugout Canoe->Geography: Grade 9

Program_Description_R3: Students learn current and historical aspects of regional and world geography with map work.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Suitable for 12th grade, and several books are shared with both 12th and 9th grade. If combining with 9th grade, it would be best to follow 9th grade lessons and add in other books as desired.
Subject: Geography
Resource_Assignments: 001.003.000*Five Months on the Missouri River: Paddling a Dugout Canoe->Geography: Grade 10-11|001.003.000*Across This Land->Geography: Grade 10-11|002.003.000*Sufferings in Africa: The Astonishing Account of a New England Sea Captain Enslaved by North African Arabs->Geography: Grade 10-11|003.003.000*All Over the Map: A Cartographic Odyssey->Geography: Grade 10-11

Program_Description_R3: Focusing mainly on travelers and places important to the year's time period, students learn regional and world geography and practice mapwork. Additionally, students spend a term on North American regional geography and dive into political geography and the ramifications of national and regional borders, which continue into the present day.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Can easily be combined with 10-11th grade.
Subject: Geography

Program_Description_R3: Get to know the diverse people who inhabited North America before Columbus arrived. Learn how they used what was available around them for food, shelter, clothing, and protection. Observe their customs and hear their stories.
Subject: History
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*The Very First Americans->History: Grade 1 (U.S.)|001.001.000*Frozen Land->History: Grade 1 (U.S.)|001.001.000*Tales the Totems Tell->History: Grade 1 (U.S.)|002.001.000*The Book of Indians->History: Grade 1 (U.S.)|002.001.000*Moonstick: The Seasons of the Sioux->History: Grade 1 (U.S.)|003.001.000*Hiawatha and the Peacemaker->History: Grade 1 (U.S.)|003.001.000*Itse Selu: Cherokee Harvest Festival->History: Grade 1 (U.S.)

Program_Description_R3: Get to know the diverse people who inhabited North America before the European explorers arrived. Learn how they used what was available around them for food, shelter, clothing, and protection. Observe their customs, hear their stories, and discover how they pass on their traditional knowledge today.
Subject: History

Program_Description_R3: Read United States history stories from the current history cycle (1800-1900). View images and reference atlases and maps to set the people and events in their time and place. Update History Charts as appropriate for student level.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: History courses are on a four-year rotation. Students should follow the current Alveary rotation.
Subject: History

Program_Description_R3: Develop Latin reading proficiency through narratives about a Roman family. Study Latin grammar and vocabulary. Build mastery through copywork, composition, narration, and dictation.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: This course may be counted as 1/2 credit for High School and is based on the same text as the Latin 1 Video Course, but without the accountability and structure of an online course platform and recorded class videos. Students work through lesson plans for the course as in other subjects.
Subject: Latin

Program_Description_R3: Develop Latin reading proficiency through narratives about a Roman family. Study Latin grammar and vocabulary. Program_Description_R3:
This course will guide students in developing meaningful skills using modern tools. Students will work hands-on with various technologies, from digital media creation to coding. Throughout the course, they will explore foundational principles and use what they have learned to solve problems and create original media while reflecting on the implications of technology and considering questions about privacy, the digital divide, and the role of innovation in society.Â This course will equip students to think critically about the world of technology and its impact on their lives and future.

NOTE: Students need a Google email account, but no books are required for this course.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: May be suitable for Grades 7-8.
Subject: Life Skills

Program_Description_R3: This course will provide the Â½ credit health requirement for those states that require it or elective credit for any student (two terms of lessons). Approached within a Charlotte Mason framework of focusing on the whole personhood of the student, this course will explore nutrition, mental health, and physical well-being.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: May be suitable for Grade 9 students
Subject: Life Skills
Resource_Assignments: 001.002.000*A Simply Healthy Life->Health Elective (Beta)|001.002.000*Body into Balance: An Herbal Guide to Holistic Self-Care->Health Elective (Beta)|002.002.000*The Joy of Movement->Health Elective (Beta)|003.002.000*Eat Well and Feel Great->Health Elective (Beta)

Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Beginners complete Lessons 1-12, which teach basic skills needed for projects.
Subject: Life Skills

Program_Description_R3: Learn and practice lettering techniques to create meaningful and inspirational hand-lettered art. Lesson topics include: serifed, sans-serifed, and script fonts, line width and value, guidelines, outlines, and shadow lines, key principles of design, dimension, and shading. Each term concludes with a project, and skills can be used to create beautiful collections of mottoes and quotes in a Commonplace Book or for display or gifts.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Suitable for interested younger students.
Subject: Life Skills
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*The Complete Book of Chalk Lettering->Lettering: Level 1

Program_Description_R3: Continue building an artistic toolbox to create hand-lettered art. Students learn to make banners, frames, and borders and practice a variety of lettering styles, including retro, faceted, vintage circus, bubble, ribbon styles, and more. Skills can be used to create beautiful collections of mottoes and quotes in a Commonplace Book or for display or gifts.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Prerequisite: Lettering Level 1
Subject: Life Skills
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*The Complete Book of Chalk Lettering->Lettering: Level 2

Program_Description_R3: Practice techniques from previous levels in new mediums - watercolor, ink and brush, brush pen. Skills can be used to create beautiful collections of mottoes and quotes in a Commonplace Book or for display or gifts.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Prerequisite: Lettering Level 2
Subject: Life Skills
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*The Complete Book of Chalk Lettering->Lettering: Level 3

Program_Description_R3: Learn typing skills with guided instruction. Includes games for practice and reinforcement. Students learn the position of each letter, number, and symbol on the keyboard and advance from typing individual letters to simple words, then paragraphs and documents. Fluency is encouraged through word-per-minute goals.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: The Typing.com website contains a placement test. Take this first, and then progress at your own pace.
Subject: Life Skills
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*Typing.com->Keyboarding

Program_Description_R3: Lessons for Grade 4 and/or those new to Shakespeare who would like a gentle on-ramp to the bard. Lessons cover A Midsummer Night's Dream over two terms.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Older students can jump into any term of the regular Shakespeare lessons after finishing these, or just read this play and take off one term.
Subject: Literature
Resource_Assignments: 001.001.000*A Midsummer Night's Dream->Shakespeare: Beginner Track|001.001.000*A Midsummer Night's Dream (Audio recording)->Shakespeare: Beginner Track

Program_Description_R3: As foundational and influential English texts, students read three Shakespeare plays per year - usually a tragedy, comedy, and a history (occasionally also connected to the historical time period). This year's plays are The Tempest, Henry IV Part 2, and The Winter's Tale.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Most Shakespeare lessons are shared with Grades 5-12. Students new to Shakespeare may choose to start with the Shakespeare Beginner Track lessons for two terms to ease into the plays.
Subject: Literature

Program_Description_R3: Students learn to love the sounds and sight of words through daily poetry reading covering a wide variety of poems. They also enjoy short picture book biographies and accessible poems corresponding to the historical time period as relevant, and lesson plans occasionally point out interesting poetic features.

Program_Description_R3: Students learn to love the sounds and sight of words and appreciate history through daily poetry reading covering a wide variety of authors and poems, some of which correspond to the historical time period (1800-1900).
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Suitable for students in Grades 5+
Subject: Literature
Resource_Assignments: 000.003.000*Jump Back, Paul: The Life and Poems of Paul Laurence Dunbar->Poetry: Grade 5

Program_Description_R3: Students continue to develop their relationship with words through daily poetry reading. Alongside a survey of poetry and poetic forms, students focus on proverbs and poems that correspond to the historical time period (1800-1900).
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: These lessons are shared with Grade 5, except for a further emphasis on poetic forms over time and poetry from the historical time period.
Subject: Literature

Program_Description_R3: Study the target language for conversation and literacy. Through picture study and the simplified fairy tales, students learn vocabulary, create sentences, and answer questions in the target language. Videos that teach the vocabulary using gestures are included in the lessons. Audio files for pronunciation help are provided as well.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: Three lessons each week are shared between Grades 1-6, but students in Grades 4-6 add two additional grammar lessons. This course is on a six-year rotation of lessons, so it is suitable for students who took Lower French last year or students just starting their studies.
Subject: Modern Language

Program_Description_R3:
Alveary Modern Language Lessons are designed to mirror the way children acquire their first language, using methods like gestures, picture recognition, songs, repeated phrases, and storytelling to create meaningful connections and context. These foundational approaches are seamlessly adapted to teach school-age children a second language.

The lessons are designed to be open-and-go with optional video/audio file support. They do not require any background in the target language for the parent/teacher or students. They only take about 15-20 min a day and can be easily adjusted to meet a variety of grade ranges from 1st to 6th grades.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3:
Three lessons each week are shared between Grades 1-6, but students in Grades 4-6 add two additional extension day lessons. This course is on a six-year rotation of lessons, so it is suitable for students who took Lower Spanish last year or students just starting their studies.

Students in grade 4+ who feel anxious about speaking a new language may benefit from taking a year without the added extension days. This approach allows them to build confidence and comfort before focusing on speaking and writing.
Subject: Modern Language

Program_Description_R3:
An accelerated course through sol-fa concepts covered in levels 1-3. Through video instruction, students will practice ear-training, Curwen hand-signs, and singing intervals from the solfa ladder. The lessons include exercises in multiple keys, time signatures, and with various rhythms. Students should already be loosely familiar with foundational music concepts such as note duration, time signatures, and how to read music on the staff.

Skills Focus: ear-training, interval recognition, sol-fa syllables, Curwen hand signs, sight-reading.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: May be suitable for a 4th grader who has knowledge of basic music concepts.
Subject: Music

Topic_List_App: General Science: Grade 1, Natural History: Grade 1, Nature Notebook: Grade 1, Nature Walks & Scouting: Grades 1-8
Program_Description_R3: In Level 1, learners are developing familiarity and friendship with Creation through the most accessible Things, simple text, and basic concepts.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: For first-grade students or those still growing their attention span or interest in books. If combining grades is desirable, it is recommended that the combined grades begin at the appropriate level and move forward together.
Subject: Science

Topic_List_App: General Science: Grade 2, Natural History: Grade 2, Nature Notebook: Grade 2, Nature Walks & Scouting: Grades 1-8
Program_Description_R3: In level 2, learners are developing familiarity and friendship with Creation through a broader scope of Things, more challenging text, and slightly more abstract concepts.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: For second-grade students or possibly hungry first-graders and third-graders taking their time. If combining grades is desirable, it is recommended that the combined grades begin at the appropriate level and move forward together.
Subject: Science

Topic_List_App: General Science: Grade 3, Natural History: Grade 3, Nature Notebook: Grade 3, Nature Walks & Scouting: Grades 1-8
Program_Description_R3: In level 3, learners are developing familiarity and friendship with Creation through a broader scope of Things, more challenging text, and more abstract concepts.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: This level 3 course is for third-grade students or possibly hungry second-graders or fourth-graders taking their time. If combining grades is desirable, it is recommended that the combined grades begin at the appropriate level and move forward together.
Subject: Science

Topic_List_App: General Science: Grade 4, Natural History: Grade 4, Labs: Grade 4, Nature Notebook: Grade 4, Nature Walks & Scouting: Grades 1-8
Program_Description_R3: In level 4, learners begin to notice science in their community and begin to develop their own interests as they discover a variety of topics from the microscopic world, physical science, and more.Â A mixture of more and less challenging books is included in this course.
Combining&PlacementTips_R3: For fourth-grade students or possibly hungry third-graders or fifth-graders taking their time. If combining grades is desirable: the combined grades may begin at the appropriate level and move forward together. Learners may stay at their appropriate level for General Science while combining Natural History and Outdoor Work, or teachers can adapt the reading level and laboratory content to meet their needs.
Subject: Science
